2) Select Help -> Help contents.

!ENTRY org.eclipse.help.ui 4 0 Mar 27, 2003 09:49:38.505
!MESSAGE Help cannot be displayed.  The embedded application server could not 
run help web application.  Check the log for details.

I cannot reproduce the problem with IBM jdk 1.3.1 and jdk 1.4.1, and using the 
same build and install path on Windows XP.

Is org.eclipse.help.webapp plugin installed and loaded correctly (Help->About-
>Plugin details?
Are you passing any options to eclipse.exe?

I start eclipse as follows:

D:\Eclipse2.0\ide\eclipse\eclipse.exe -vm D:\Eclipse2.0\vm\jre\bin\java -ws 
win32 -os win32 -vmargs -Xmx256M

All I did was unzip the eclipse SDK into an empty directory.  How do I check 
if the plugin is correctly installed?

Choose Help->About from the menu, then click Plugin details and check if the 
org.eclipse.help.webapp plugin v. 2.1 is in the list.
org.eclipse.help.webapp plugin 2.1.0 appears in the list of plugins.

Walking through the steps in the debugger, I get the following:

In PluginDescriptor.findInPlugin(URL install, IPath filePath) line 985,

    URL location = new URL(install, filePath.toString());

an IOException is thrown and null is returned.

The filePath.toString() is EMPTY_STRING.

The install variable at this point looks like this:

   install= URL  (id=62)
	authority= null
	file= "D:/Eclipse2.0/ide/eclipse/workspace/org.eclipse.help.webapp/"
	handler= Handler  (id=89)
	hashCode= -1
	host= ""
	hostAddress= null
	path= "D:/Eclipse2.0/ide/eclipse/workspace/org.eclipse.help.webapp/"
	port= -1
	protocol= "file"
	query= null
	ref= null
	userInfo= null

The stack trace to this point is:

Thread [main] (Suspended)

	Workbench.run(Object) line: 1385
	InternalBootLoader.run(String, URL, String, String[], Runnable) line: 
845
	BootLoader.run(String, URL, String, String[], Runnable) line: 461
	Method.invoke(Object, Object[]) line: not available [native method]
	Main.basicRun(String[]) line: 291
	Main.run(String[]) line: 747
	Main.main(String[]) line: 583

Thanks Veronika.
I tried creating an install path just like yours (but on my Win2K machine) 
using the latest driver and could not reproduce the problem.
From the stack trace it appears that the PluginDescriptor may have a bug. 
Should we ping someone from Core ?

Just to make sure we understand:
The second argument of PluginDescriptor.findInPlugin is supposed to be an empty 
string "", not a string "EMPTY_STRING".
If this is not true than it would be a core bug.

If this is true, then it looks like a bug in older JDK that might have problem 
with Windows XP.
Veronika, could you start Eclipse using newer JDK and try launching Help?
Thanks.

Tried with:

java.runtime.name=Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition
java.runtime.version=1.4.0-b92
java.specification.name=Java Platform API Specification
java.specification.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
java.specification.version=1.4

This time it works.

Thanks a lot for investigating this.
The JDK that has problem J2RE 1.3.0 IBM build cn130-20010329 is 2 years old, 
was released prior to Windows XP.  It is obsolete.
I will resolve the bug as WONTFIX.  Please reopen if you see the a problem with 
JDK versions that Eclipse supports or newer.

I agree with marking this bug report as a VM problem.

org.eclipse.core.runtime.Path.toString() makes reference to a constant called 
EMPTY_STRING. It is suspicious that the VM is returning the name of the 
constant rather than the constant value. ("")

Note, the org.eclipse.core.runtime.Path.toString() is returning the constant 
EMPTY_STRING not the string "EMPTY_STRING".  This is not the issue.

Looking at the code, filePath will be an empty path the first time the method 
is called.
*** Bug 37385 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 37413 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 38905 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
